post.subject: Re: Slide no 8: control effort stability
post.message: This is identical to the situation where the control effort is available for free - recall the room cooling example that I gave in the last class.  Naturally, the control effort can go unbounded.  The solution is to bound the control effort as well.  A way to overcome this difficulty is given in slide 10.

post.subject: Re: Slide 27/32 - bias
post.message: The difference between actual measurement of the output, namely y and the model predicted value $$\hat y$$ is known as the bias here.  We assume the bias to be the same for all future time instants in DMC.

post.subject: Re: slide 9
post.message: Fat matrix of G is equivalent to fitting more number of parameters using less number of data points.  An example of this situation is to give only two points and to try to fit a sine curve through it.  In contrast, a tall matrix of G is equivalent to fitting a straight line through three or more points.

post.subject: Re: slide 17 re estimating the model
post.message:
Yes, u(n+1) is never used, although it is calculated at every time instant.  Same thing happens for u(n+2), u(n+3), etc.

Although the future control moves are never used, they still need to be calculated.  Although they are never used, they influence the calculation of u(n) itself, tempering it, as it were.  As a result, even though the future control moves are not used directly, their indirect use is of great significance.

post.subject: Re: Use of the bias term
post.message: The GPC approach has a rigorous noise model.  It will make more sense to re-calculate the model parameters also, at every time step, or whenever possible/required.  This is because the bias term approach is just a "fix", involving a crude approximation that the bias term remains constant throughout the future.  Such an approximation is required only when other options don't exist, for example in DMC, where the noise is not even modelled.

post.subject: Re: Detrmination of Control Horizon
post.message: The control horizon and also the prediction horizon are tuning parameters in all MPC.  Control horizon is smaller than the prediction horizon.

post.subject: Re: 16th lecture: slide 18
post.message: It is selected by trial and error.  Based on the domain knowledge and past experience, one comes up with an initial value of $$\rho$$.  If the resulting control effort is unacceptably large, increase $$\rho$$ and re-calculate the control law.  If the control is ineffective, however, and if the control effort can be increased, decrease $$\rho$$ instead.

post.subject: Re: slide 9 : least square problem
post.message: In the equation Gu = b+e, we want to calculate u such that e is made zero.  In other words, we want to solve Gu=b.  As this is not a square system, there is no solution in strict sense.  One option is to invoke the least squares approach.

post.subject: Re: Slide 3: Ny > Nu
post.message: This can be explained with a simple example.  Suppose that the control effort has to be changed by a constant value, i.e. a step change.  Suppose also that the control effort remains constant thereafter.  Depending on the settling time of the system, this control change will influence the output value for a long time.  Ny should be large enough to capture all these changes.

post.subject: Re: slide 19: Reducing computing time
post.message:
You have two questions:

Can we calculate u at just one time instant?  The answer is no.  Please see the answer that I gave to Sudeesh.

Can we avoid calculating the inverse at every time instant?  The answer is "Yes".  This method is called recursive least squares.  This involves "adjusting" the solution calculated in the last time step, based on the changes in the G matrix, in the equation Gu = b.

Of course, it should be understood that one never "inverts" any matrix in the calculation of K.  One just solves it by Gaussian elimination or similar methods.

post.subject: Re: slide 32: Model for the bias
post.message: No, we cannot do that.  The model that you have proposed will work only for deterministic systems.  It will not work when one of the elements is noise, which changes randomly.
